translated: Composed by Venerable Vasubandhu
Translated by Tripiá¹­aka Master Xuanzang on Imperial Order

In the seventh part of the eighth chapter, Discerning the Thousand Questions, it is asked how many have the body view as a cause but are not causes of the body view, and so on. All should be distinguished.
Namely, the form aggregate, if defiled, has the body view as a cause but is not a cause of the body view; if undefiled, it neither has the body view as a cause nor is a cause of the body view.
The feeling aggregate has three cases.

It may have the body view as a cause but not be a cause of the body view, referring to the defiled feeling aggregate except for that associated with the latent tendencies eliminated by the path of seeing suffering in the past and present, and except for that associated with the omnipresent latent tendencies eliminated by the path of seeing the origin in the past and present, as well as the feeling aggregate associated with the body view in the future.
It may have the body view as a cause and also be a cause of the body view, referring to the feeling aggregate excluded above.
It may neither have the body view as a cause nor be a cause of the body view, referring to the undefiled feeling aggregate.
The same applies to the aggregates of perception and consciousness.
The aggregate of formations has three sentences.

Either with the view of self as real as its cause but not as its effect, referring to the aggregate of formations associated with and coexisting with the latent afflictions eliminated by the path of seeing suffering in the past and present, as well as the aggregate of formations associated with and coexisting with the pervasive latent afflictions eliminated by the path of seeing the origin in the past and present, as well as the aggregate of formations associated with the view of self as real in the future, as well as the arising, aging, enduring, and impermanence of the view of self as real and dharmas associated with it in the future, and all other defiled aggregates of formations.
Either with the view of self as real as its cause and also as its effect, referring to the aggregate of formations excluded above.
Either not with the view of self as real as its cause or as its effect, referring to the undefiled aggregate of formations.
As for how many are karma and how many are not karmic retribution, etc., all should be discriminated.
That is, the aggregate of form has three sentences.
Either karma but not karmic retribution, referring to bodily and verbal karma.
Or, it is karmic retribution but not karma, namely, the form aggregate born of karmic retribution.
Or, it is neither karma nor karmic retribution, namely, the remaining form aggregates other than karma and the form aggregate born of karmic retribution.
The feeling aggregate is either karmic retribution but not karma, or neither karma nor karmic retribution.
Karmic retribution but not karma refers to the feeling aggregate born of karmic retribution. The remaining feeling aggregates are neither karma nor karmic retribution.
The perception and consciousness aggregates are also like this.
The formation aggregate has four alternatives.ğŸ”½Or it is karma but not karmic retribution, namely, volition not included in karmic retribution.
Or it is karmic retribution but not karma, namely, the formation aggregate born of karmic retribution not included in volition.
Or it is both karma and karmic retribution, namely, volition born of karmic retribution.
Or it is neither karma nor karmic retribution, namely, the remaining formation aggregates other than karma and the formation aggregate born of karmic retribution.
How many are karma but not concomitant with karma, etc.? Three are concomitant with karma but not karma, two should be distinguished.
The form aggregate has three sentences.
Either it is action but not that which is concomitant with action, referring to all the other bodily and verbal actions except for those that are concomitant with action.
Or it is both action and that which is concomitant with action, referring to bodily and verbal actions that are concomitant with action.
Or it is neither action nor that which is concomitant with action, referring to all the other form aggregates except for those that are action and those that are concomitant with action.
The formation aggregate has three sentences.

Either it is action but not that which is concomitant with action, referring to volition.ğŸ”½Or it is that which is concomitant with action but not action, referring to the formation aggregate that is concomitant with action but not included in volition.
Or it is neither action nor that which is concomitant with action, referring to all the other formations that are not concomitant with the mind except for those that are concomitant with action.

As for how many are derivative form but not visible form, and so on, four are neither derivative form nor visible form, and one should be distinguished, namely, the form aggregate has three sentences.
Either it is derivative form but not visible form, referring to the eight sense bases and part of two sense bases.
Or, visible form that is derivative form, namely one sense base.
Or, neither derivative form nor visible form, namely one part of one sense base.
As for these five aggregates, how many are derivative form but not resistant form, etc.? Four are neither derivative form nor resistant form. One should be distinguished.
That is to say, the form aggregate should be made into four sentences.ğŸ”½Either derivative form but not resistant form, namely one part of one sense base.
Either resistant form but not derivative form, namely one part of one sense base.
Either derivative form and also resistant form, namely nine sense bases and one part of one sense base.
Either neither derivative form nor resistant form, such form cannot be obtained.
As for how many are difficult to see and therefore profound, etc., all are difficult to see and therefore profound, and profoundly difficult to see.
As for how many are wholesome but not causes of the wholesome, etc., all should be distinguished.
That is to say, each has three sentences.
Or, it is a cause of what is wholesome but not wholesome itself, namely, the five aggregates arisen from the retribution of what is wholesome.
Or, it is both wholesome and a cause of what is wholesome, namely, the five wholesome aggregates.
Or, it is neither wholesome nor a cause of what is wholesome, namely, the five aggregates other than those arisen from the retribution of what is wholesome, and the unwholesome five aggregates.
As for how many are unwholesome but not a cause of what is unwholesome, etc., all should be discriminated.
That is to say, the aggregate of form has three cases.
Or, it is a cause of what is unwholesome but not unwholesome itself, namely, the aggregate of form arisen from the retribution of what is unwholesome.
Or, it is both unwholesome and a cause of what is unwholesome, namely, the aggregate of form that is unwholesome.

Or, it is neither unwholesome nor a cause of what is unwholesome, namely, the other indeterminate aggregates of form, and the wholesome aggregate of form, excluding the aggregate of form arisen from the retribution of what is unwholesome.
The aggregate of feeling has three cases.

Or, it is a cause of what is unwholesome but not unwholesome itself, namely, the aggregate of feeling arisen from the retribution of what is unwholesome, and the aggregate of feeling associated with the view of existence and the view of grasping extremes belonging to the desire realm.
Or, it is unwholesome and also has unwholesome as its cause, namely, the aggregate of feeling that is unwholesome.

Or, it is neither unwholesome nor has unwholesome as its cause, namely, the aggregate of feeling that is wholesome, and the aggregate of feeling that is non-defined, excluding the aggregate of feeling that arises from the retribution of unwholesome [action], and excluding the aggregate of feeling associated with the view of existence in the realm of desire and the view of grasping extremes in the realm of desire.
The aggregates of perception and consciousness are also like this.
The aggregate of volitional formations has three cases.

Or, it has unwholesome as its cause but is not unwholesome, namely, the aggregate of volitional formations that arises from the retribution of unwholesome [action], and the view of existence and the view of grasping extremes in the realm of desire, and the aggregate of volitional formations that is associated with them and arises together with them.
Or, it is unwholesome and also has unwholesome as its cause, namely, the aggregate of volitional formations that is unwholesome.

Or, it is neither unwholesome nor has unwholesome as its cause, namely, the aggregate of volitional formations that is non-defined, excluding the aggregate of volitional formations that arises from the retribution of unwholesome [action], and excluding the view of existence and the view of grasping extremes in the realm of desire, and the aggregate of volitional formations that is associated with them and arises together with them, and the aggregate of volitional formations that is wholesome.
How many are indeterminate and not causes of indeterminate dharmas? All should be distinguished, each having three sentences.
Either indeterminate and not causes of indeterminate dharmas, referring to the five aggregates of unwholesomeness.
Either indeterminate and causes of indeterminate dharmas, referring to the five aggregates of indeterminate dharmas.
Either not indeterminate and not causes of indeterminate dharmas, referring to the five aggregates of wholesomeness.
How many are conditions and have causes? All are conditions and also have causes.
How many are immediately antecedent and not conditions of immediacy? One is neither immediately antecedent nor a condition of immediacy, four should be distinguished.

That is to say, the aggregate of feeling has three sentences.ğŸ”½Either immediately antecedent and not a condition of immediacy, referring to the aggregate of feeling that is presently arising in the future, and the aggregate of feeling at the time of the final death of an arhat in the past and present.

Either immediately antecedent and also a condition of immediacy, referring to all past and present aggregates of feeling except for the aggregate of feeling at the time of the final death of an arhat in the past and present.

Or neither a condition as the equivalent and immediate antecedent nor a condition as the equivalent and immediate antecedent, namely, all the other future aggregates of feeling, with the exception of those that are presently arising.
The same applies to the aggregates of perception and consciousness.

The aggregate of formations has three alternatives.ğŸ”½It is either a condition as the equivalent and immediate antecedent but not a condition as the equivalent and immediate antecedent, namely, the aggregate of mental formations that are presently arising in the future, and the aggregate of mental formations of an arhat in the past and present at the moment of entering final nirvÄá¹‡a, as well as the formations that have already arisen and are presently occurring in the two mindless meditative absorptions.ğŸ”½It is both a condition as the equivalent and immediate antecedent and a condition as the equivalent and immediate antecedent, namely, all the aggregates of mental formations in the past and present, with the exception of the aggregate of mental formations of an arhat in the past and present at the moment of entering final nirvÄá¹‡a.

Or neither a condition as the equivalent and immediate antecedent nor a condition as the equivalent and immediate antecedent, namely, all the other future aggregates of mental formations, with the exception of those that are presently arising, and all the other formations dissociated from thought, with the exception of those that are conditions as the equivalent and immediate antecedent of thought.

How many are objects of observation conditions but not having objects of observation? One is an object of observation condition but not having an object of observation. Three are both object of observation conditions and having objects of observation. One should be differentiated.

That is to say, the aggregate of karmic forces. If it is a mental factor, it is an object of observation condition and also has an object of observation. If it is not a mental factor, it is an object of observation condition but does not have an object of observation.
How many are dominant conditions but not having dominance? All are dominant conditions and also have dominance.
How many are floods but not in conformity with floods? All should be differentiated.
That is to say, the form aggregate. If it is contaminated, it is in conformity with floods but not a flood. If it is uncontaminated, it is neither a flood nor in conformity with floods.
The aggregates of feeling, perception, and consciousness are also like this.
The aggregate of karmic forces has three sentences.
Either in conformity with floods but not a flood, referring to the contaminated aggregate of karmic forces not included in the floods.
Either a flood and also in conformity with floods, referring to the four floods.
Or they are neither a flood nor that which is favorable to a flood, namely the pure aggregates of form, etc.
The eighteen elements are the eye element, form element, eye-consciousness element, and so on up to the mind element, the factors element, and mind-consciousness element.
Among these eighteen elements, how many are material, etc.? Ten are material, seven are immaterial, and one should be distinguished.
Namely, the factors element is either material or immaterial.
How is it material?
It is the bodily and verbal actions included in the factors element. The rest of the factors element is immaterial.
How many are visible, etc.? One is visible, seventeen are invisible.
How many are resistant, etc.? Ten are resistant, eight are non-resistant.
How many are contaminated, etc.? Fifteen are contaminated, three should be distinguished.
Namely, the mind element is either contaminated or uncontaminated.
How is it contaminated?
It is the mind element associated with contaminated attention.
How is it uncontaminated?
It is the mind element associated with uncontaminated attention.
The same applies to the consciousness realm of the mental faculty.
The dharma realm may be either contaminated or uncontaminated.
What is contaminated?
It refers to the contaminated bodily and verbal actions included in the dharma realm, as well as the contaminated aggregates of feeling, perception, and mental formations.
What is uncontaminated?
It refers to the uncontaminated bodily and verbal actions, the uncontaminated aggregates of feeling, perception, and mental formations, as well as unconditioned dharmas.
How many are conditioned, etc.? Seventeen are conditioned, one should be distinguished.
That is, the dharma realm may be either conditioned or unconditioned.
What is conditioned?
It refers to the bodily and verbal actions included in the dharma realm, as well as the aggregates of feeling, perception, and mental formations.
What is unconditioned?
It refers to space and the two cessations.
How many have karmic retribution, etc.? Eight have no karmic retribution, ten should be distinguished.
That is, the form realm may have karmic retribution or be without karmic retribution.
What has karmic retribution?
It refers to wholesome and unwholesome form realms.
What is without karmic retribution?
It refers to indeterminate form realms and sounds.
The five consciousnesses are also like this.
The mind element may have retribution or may not have retribution.
What has retribution?
It is the unwholesome and wholesome contaminated mind element.
What does not have retribution?
It is the indeterminate and uncontaminated mind element.
The dharma element and mind consciousness element are also like this.
As for how many are born from causes and conditions, etc., seventeen are born from causes and conditions, born from causes, and included in the world. One should be distinguished.

That is, the dharma element, if conditioned, is born from causes and conditions, born from causes, and included in the world. If unconditioned, it is not born from causes and conditions, not born from causes, and not included in the world.
As for how many are categorized as form, etc., ten are categorized as form, seven are categorized as name, and one should be distinguished.
That is, the dharma element that subsumes bodily and verbal karma is categorized as form, the rest are all categorized as name.
As for how many are categorized as internal sense bases, etc., twelve are categorized as internal sense bases, six are categorized as external sense bases.
How many are known by the knowledge of non-arising? All are known by the knowledge of non-arising.
How many are known by the knowledge of the destruction of defilements? Fifteen are known by the knowledge of the destruction of defilements, three should be distinguished.

That is, the mental, dharma, and mind consciousness elements: if they are contaminated, they are known by the knowledge of the destruction of defilements; if they are uncontaminated, they are not known by the knowledge of the destruction of defilements.
How many should be eliminated? Fifteen should be eliminated, three should be distinguished.
That is, the mental, dharma, and mind consciousness elements: if they are contaminated, they should be eliminated; if they are uncontaminated, they should not be eliminated.
How many should be cultivated? Eight should not be cultivated, ten should be distinguished.
That is, the form element, either should be cultivated or should not be cultivated.
How should it be cultivated?
That is, the wholesome form element.
How should it not be cultivated?
That is, the unwholesome and indeterminate form element.
The sound element, the six consciousness elements, and the mind element are also like this.
The dharma realm may be either to be cultivated or not to be cultivated.
What is to be cultivated?
It refers to the wholesome conditioned dharma realm.
What is not to be cultivated?
It refers to the unwholesome, indeterminate dharma realm, and cessation through discernment.
As for how many are defiled, etc., eight are not defiled, and ten should be distinguished.
It means the form realm may be either defiled or undefiled.
What is defiled?
It refers to the form realm that is covered.
What is undefiled?
It refers to the form realm that is not covered.
The sound realm, the six consciousness realms, and the mind and dharma realms are also like this.
As for how many are results but not possess results, etc., seventeen are results and also possess results, and one should be distinguished.
It means the dharma realm has three sentences.
Either it is a result but does not possess results, referring to cessation through discernment.
Either it is a result and also possesses results, referring to the conditioned dharma realm.
Or it is neither a result nor possesses results, referring to space and cessation not through discernment.
How many are with attachment? Nine are without attachment, nine should be distinguished.
That is to say, the eye element, either with attachment or without attachment.
How is it with attachment?
It refers to the eye element included in one's own body.
How is it without attachment?
It refers to the eye element not included in one's own body.
The form, ear, nose, smell, tongue, taste, body, and touch elements are also like this.
How many are derived from the great elements? Nine and two parts are derived from the great elements, seven and two parts are not derived from the great elements.
How many have a superior? Seventeen have a superior, one should be distinguished.
That is to say, the dharma element, either with a superior or without a superior.
How is it with a superior?
It refers to the conditioned dharma element, space, and non-analytical cessation.
How is it without a superior?
It refers to analytical cessation.
How many are existent? Fifteen are existent, three should be distinguished.
It means the mental faculty, dharmas, and the mental consciousness realm. If they are contaminated, they are existence. If they are uncontaminated, they are not existence.
As for how many are causes and how many are concomitant, seven are causes and concomitant, ten are causes but not concomitant, and one should be distinguished.
It means the dharma realm. If it is a mental factor, it is a cause and concomitant. If it is not a mental factor, it is a cause but not concomitant.
As for how the eighteen realms are included in the six wholesome bases, the six wholesome bases include part of ten realms, and part of ten realms also includes the six wholesome bases.
As for how they are included in the five unwholesome bases, the five unwholesome bases include part of ten realms, and part of ten realms also includes the five unwholesome bases.

As for how they are included in the seven indeterminate bases, the seven indeterminate bases include eight realms and part of ten realms, and eight realms and part of ten realms also include the seven indeterminate bases.

As for how they are included in the three contaminated bases, the three contaminated bases include part of one realm, and part of one realm also includes the three contaminated bases.ğŸ”½Here is the corrected and aligned text:

As for the relationship with the five contaminated sense bases, the five contaminated sense bases include fifteen sense fields and part of three sense fields, and fifteen sense fields and part of three sense fields also include the five contaminated sense bases.

As for the relationship with the eight uncontaminated sense bases, the eight uncontaminated sense bases include part of three sense fields, and part of three sense fields also includes the eight uncontaminated sense bases.
As for how many are past, etc., seventeen are either past, future, or present, and one should be distinguished.
That is to say, the sense field of mental objects, if conditioned, is either past, future, or present, but if unconditioned, it is neither past, future, nor present.
As for how many are wholesome, etc., eight are indeterminate, and ten should be distinguished.
That is to say, the sense field of form is either wholesome, unwholesome, or indeterminate.
What is wholesome?
It refers to wholesome bodily expression.
What is unwholesome?
It refers to unwholesome bodily expression.
What is indeterminate?
It refers to the sense field of form other than wholesome and unwholesome bodily expression.
The sound element may be wholesome, unwholesome, or indeterminate.
What is wholesome?
It refers to wholesome bodily and verbal expressions.
What is unwholesome?
It refers to unwholesome bodily and verbal expressions.
What is indeterminate?
It refers to the sound element other than wholesome and unwholesome bodily and verbal expressions.
The eye-consciousness element may be wholesome, unwholesome, or indeterminate.
What is wholesome?
It refers to eye-consciousness associated with wholesome attention.
What is unwholesome?
It refers to eye-consciousness associated with unwholesome attention.
What is indeterminate?
It refers to eye-consciousness associated with indeterminate attention.
The other five consciousness elements and the mind element are also like this.
The dharma element may be wholesome, unwholesome, or indeterminate.
What is wholesome?

It refers to the wholesome bodily and verbal actions included in the dharma element, as well as the wholesome aggregates of feeling, perception, and formation, and also cessation through deliberation.
What is unwholesome?
It refers to the unwholesome bodily and verbal actions included in the dharma element, as well as the unwholesome aggregates of feeling, perception, and formation.
What is neutral?
It refers to neutral feeling, perception, and the aggregates of mental formations, as well as space and non-analytical cessation.
How many are bound to the desire realm, etc.? Four are bound to the desire realm, and fourteen should be distinguished.
That is to say, the eye element is either bound to the desire realm or bound to the form realm.
How is it bound to the desire realm?
It refers to the eye element that is produced from the great elements of the desire realm.
How is it bound to the form realm?
It refers to the eye element that is produced from the great elements of the form realm.
The elements of form, ear, sound, nose, tongue, and body are also like this.
The element of touch is either bound to the desire realm or bound to the form realm.
How is it bound to the desire realm?
It refers to the element of touch that is produced from the four great elements of the desire realm.
How is it bound to the form realm?
It refers to the element of touch that is produced from the four great elements of the form realm.
The eye consciousness element is either bound to the desire realm or bound to the form realm.
How is it bound to the desire realm?
It refers to eye consciousness associated with attention of the desire realm.
How is it related to the form realm?
It refers to eye consciousness associated with the attention of the form realm.
The same applies to the ear and body consciousnesses.
The mind element may be related to the desire realm, the form realm, the formless realm, or it may be unconditioned.
How is it related to the desire realm?
It refers to the mind element associated with the attention of the desire realm.
How is it related to the form realm?
It refers to the mind element associated with the attention of the form realm.
How is it related to the formless realm?
It refers to the mind element associated with the attention of the formless realm.
How is it unconditioned?
It refers to the mind element associated with uncontaminated attention.
The same applies to the mind consciousness element.
The dharma element may be related to the desire realm, the form realm, the formless realm, or it may be unconditioned.
How is it related to the desire realm?
It refers to the desire realm aggregates of form, speech, and the mental formations included in the dharma element, as well as the feeling and conceptualization aggregates of the desire realm.
How is it related to the form realm?
Namely, the form aggregate included in the dharma realm, bodily and verbal actions, and the aggregates of feeling, perception, and formation in the form realm.
What is associated with the formless realm?
Namely, the aggregates of feeling, perception, and formation in the formless realm.
What is unassociated?
Namely, the pure bodily and verbal actions, the aggregates of feeling, perception, and formation in the pure aggregates, and unconditioned dharmas.
As for how many are learner dharmas, etc., fifteen are neither learner nor post-learner dharmas, and three should be distinguished.
Namely, the mind realm is either a learner dharma, a post-learner dharma, or neither a learner nor a post-learner dharma.
What is a learner dharma?
It refers to the mind realm associated with the attention of a learner.
What is a post-learner dharma?
It refers to the mind realm associated with the attention of a post-learner.
What is neither a learner nor a post-learner dharma?
It refers to the mind realm associated with the attention of one who is neither a learner nor a post-learner.
The mind consciousness realm is also like this.
The dharma realm is either a learner dharma, a post-learner dharma, or neither a learner nor a post-learner dharma.
What is a learner dharma?
It refers to the bodily and verbal actions of a learner, and the aggregates of feeling, perception, and formation in a learner.
What are those that are not learners?
They are the bodily and verbal actions of those beyond training, and the aggregates of feeling, perception, and mental formations of those beyond training.
What are those that are neither learners nor those beyond training?
They are the bodily and verbal actions included in the element of dharmas, the aggregates of feeling, perception, and mental formations that are contaminated, and unconditioned dharmas.
Among these eighteen elements, how many are to be eliminated by seeing, and so on? Fifteen are to be eliminated by cultivation. Three should be distinguished.
The mind element is either to be eliminated by seeing, or to be eliminated by cultivation, or not to be eliminated.
What is to be eliminated by seeing?
It is the mind element that is eliminated by the receptivity at the end of the uninterrupted stage of the path of seeing of those who follow the teachings by faith or by the teachings.
What is that again?
It is the mind element associated with the eighty-eight latent afflictions to be eliminated by seeing.
What is to be eliminated by cultivation?
It is the mind element that is to be eliminated by cultivation by those who have entered the path of cultivation and have seen the truths.
What is that again?
It is the mind element associated with the ten latent afflictions to be eliminated by cultivation, and the defiled and contaminated mind element.
What is not to be eliminated?
It is the pure mind element.
The same applies to the consciousness element of the mind.
The element of mental objects is either to be eliminated by the path of insight, or to be eliminated by the path of cultivation, or not to be eliminated.
What is to be eliminated by the path of insight?
It is that which is to be eliminated by the acceptance of the cognition of the factors with regard to the truths in the path of insight of the adherents of faith and the adherents of the doctrine.
What is this?
It is the eighty-eight proclivities to be eliminated by the path of insight, and the element of mental objects associated with them, and the formations dissociated from thought produced by them.
What is to be eliminated by the path of cultivation?
It is that which is to be eliminated by the path of cultivation of the adherents of the doctrine who have entered the path of insight.
What is this?

It is the ten proclivities to be eliminated by the path of cultivation, and the element of mental objects associated with them, and the bodily and vocal actions produced by them, and the formations dissociated from thought, and the impure element of mental objects that are not defiled.
What is not to be eliminated?
It is the pure element of mental objects.
How many are not mind, etc.? Ten are neither mind nor mental factors nor associated with mind. Seven are only mind. One should be differentiated.
That is, the dharma realm. If it has an object, it is a mental factor associated with the mind. If it has no object, it is neither a mind nor a mental factor, nor associated with the mind.

How many are concomitant with the mind but not associated with feeling, etc.? Ten are neither concomitant with the mind nor associated with feeling. Seven are associated with feeling but not concomitant with the mind. One should be distinguished.
That is, the dharma realm has three phrases.

Either concomitant with the mind but not associated with feeling, referring to bodily and verbal actions that are concomitant with the mind, factors not directly associated with the mind, and feeling.
Either concomitant with the mind and also associated with feeling, referring to the aggregate of perception and the aggregate of mental activities that are associated [with the mind].

Either not concomitant with the mind and not associated with feeling, referring to bodily and verbal actions and factors not directly associated with the mind that are not concomitant with the mind, and unconditioned dharmas other than those bodily and verbal actions and factors not directly associated with the mind that are concomitant with the mind.
How many are concomitant with the mind but not associated with conceptualization and volition, etc.? Excluding its own nature, it should be understood like feeling.

How many are associated with applied thought but not with sustained thought? Ten are not associated with applied thought or sustained thought. Five are associated with both applied thought and sustained thought. Three should be discriminated.

That is, the mind element is either associated with applied thought and sustained thought, or it is without applied thought but only with sustained thought, or it is without either applied thought or sustained thought.
What is associated with applied thought and sustained thought?
It is the mind element associated with applied thought and sustained thought.
What is without applied thought but only with sustained thought?
It is the mind element associated with sustained thought only.
What is without either applied thought or sustained thought?
It is the mind element associated with neither applied thought nor sustained thought.
The same applies to the mind consciousness element.

The dharma element has four alternatives.ğŸ”½Either it is associated with applied thought but not with sustained thought, referring to the formations dissociated from the mind that are associated with applied thought, and sustained thought associated with applied thought.

Or it is associated with sustained thought but not with applied thought, referring to applied thought and the mental factors associated with sustained thought that are not associated with applied thought.
Or, it is associated with both applied thought and sustained thought, namely, the mental factors associated with applied thought and sustained thought.

Or, it is neither associated with applied thought nor associated with sustained thought, namely, the bodily and verbal actions and the dissociated factors other than those associated with sustained thought, the sustained thought not associated with applied thought, the mental factors not associated with applied thought or sustained thought, and the unconditioned dharmas.
As for how many are views and how many are objects of views, etc., one is both a view and an object of views, fourteen are objects of views but not views, and three should be distinguished.
Namely, the mind element: if it is contaminated, it is an object of views but not a view; if it is uncontaminated, it is neither a view nor an object of views.
The same applies to the mind consciousness element.
The dharma element has four alternatives.
Or it is a view but not an object of views, namely, the uncontaminated discernment not included in the knowledge of elimination and non-production.
Or it is an object of views but not a view, namely, the contaminated dharma element not included in the views.
Or it is both a view and an object of views, namely, the five defiled views and worldly right views.
Or neither seen nor seen as a basis, referring to the uncontaminated dharma realm not included in the seen.

As for how many have the view of self as their cause but are not themselves the view of self, eight do not have the view of self as their cause and are not themselves the view of self. Ten should be distinguished.

That is, the form realm, if defiled, has the view of self as its cause but is not itself the view of self; if undefiled, it does not have the view of self as its cause and is not itself the view of self.
The sound realm and the five consciousness realms are also like this.

analyzed: æ„è­˜ç•Œï¼Œæˆ–æœ‰èº«è¦‹ç‚ºå› éæœ‰èº«è¦‹å› ã€æˆ–æœ‰èº«è¦‹ç‚ºå› äº¦æœ‰èº«è¦‹å› ã€æˆ–éæœ‰èº«è¦‹ç‚ºå› éæœ‰èº«è¦‹å› ã€‚
translated: The mental consciousness realm, either has the view of self as its cause but is not itself the view of self, or has the view of self as its cause and is itself the view of self, or does not have the view of self as its cause and is not itself the view of self.

The manas element that is a cause of the view of the real existence of the body but is not a cause of the view of the real existence of the body is the manas element associated with the proclivities eliminated during the path of seeing that are abandoned by the path of seeing the truths of suffering and of the origin, and also the manas element associated with the proclivities eliminated during the path of seeing that are eliminated by the path of seeing the truth of suffering and are of the category of universal proclivities, and also the manas element associated with the view of the real existence of the body in the future. All other defiled manas elements are not a cause of the view of the real existence of the body.
The manas element that is a cause of the view of the real existence of the body and is also a cause of the view of the real existence of the body is the manas element that was previously excluded.
The manas element that is not a cause of the view of the real existence of the body and is not a cause of the view of the real existence of the body is the undefiled manas element.
The same applies to the consciousness element.
The dharma element has three sentences.

There may be a dharma realm that is a cause of the view of self but not a cause of the view of self, namely, excluding the dharma realm of past and present suffering-eliminated afflictions and the dharmas associated with them and coexisting with them, also excluding the dharma realm of past and present accumulation-eliminated universal afflictions and the dharmas associated with them and coexisting with them, also excluding the future dharma realm associated with the view of self, also excluding the future view of self and the birth, aging, duration, and impermanence of those associated dharmas, and all other defiled dharma realms.
There may be a dharma realm that is a cause of the view of self and also a cause of the view of self, namely, the dharma realms excluded above.
There may be a dharma realm that is neither a cause of the view of self nor a cause of the view of self, namely, the undefiled dharma realm.
How many are karma but not karmic maturation, etc.? All should be discriminated.
The eye realm may be karmic maturation but not karma, or it may be neither karma nor karmic maturation.
Karmic maturation but not karma refers to the eye realm that is born of karmic maturation.
Those that are neither karma nor karmic results are the other eye elements.
The ear, nose, tongue, body, smell, taste, and touch elements, as well as the seven mental elements, are also like this.
The form element has three sentences.
Either karma but not karmic results, referring to bodily expression.ğŸ”½Either karmic results but not karma, referring to the form element that is a karmic result.
Either not karma and not karmic results, referring to the form element other than karma and karmic results.
The sound element has two sentences.
Either karma but not karmic results, referring to verbal expression.
Either not karma and not karmic results, referring to the other sound elements.
The dharma element has four sentences.
Either karma but not karmic results, referring to the bodily and verbal actions included in the dharma element, as well as volition not included in karmic results.
Either karmic results but not karma, referring to the dharmas that are karmic results not included in volition.
Either karma and also karmic results, referring to the volition that is a karmic result.
Or neither karma nor karmic ripening, referring to the remaining dharmas in the dharma realm, excluding karma and karmic ripening.
How many are karmic but not karmic precursors? Seven are karmic precursors but not karmic, eight are neither karmic nor karmic precursors, three should be distinguished.
That is, the form realm, either karma but not a karmic precursor, or neither karma nor a karmic precursor.
Karma but not a karmic precursor refers to bodily expression.
Neither karma nor a karmic precursor refers to the remaining form realm.
The sound realm, either karma but not a karmic precursor, or neither karma nor a karmic precursor.
Karma but not a karmic precursor refers to verbal expression.
Neither karma nor a karmic precursor refers to the remaining sound realm.
The dharma realm has four possibilities.
Either karma but not a karmic precursor, referring to bodily and verbal karma included in the dharma realm that is not a karmic precursor, and volition.
Or it is that which is concomitant with action but not action, namely, the aggregate of feeling, the aggregate of conception, and the aggregate of formations not included in action.
Or it is both action and that which is concomitant with action, namely, bodily and vocal action.
Or it is neither action nor that which is concomitant with action, namely, the rest of the elements of the element of mental objects.
As to how many are visible form and how many are not visible form, etc., there are three alternatives.
Or it is visible form but not form derived from the elements, namely, eight elements and part of two elements.
Or it is both visible form and form derived from the elements, namely, one element.
Or it is neither visible form nor form derived from the elements, namely, seven elements and part of two elements.

As to how many are form derived from the elements but are not resistant, etc., there are four alternatives.ğŸ”½Or it is form derived from the elements but is not resistant, namely, part of one element.
Or it is resistant but is not form derived from the elements, namely, part of one element.
Or, derivative form is also resistant form, namely the nine elements and a part of one element.
Or, it is neither derivative form nor resistant form, namely seven elements and a part of one element.
As to how many are difficult to see because they are profound, etc.: all are difficult to see because they are profound, and they are profound because they are difficult to see.
As to how many are wholesome but not causes of the wholesome, etc.: all should be discriminated.
That is to say, the eye element is either a cause of the wholesome but not wholesome, or neither a cause of the wholesome nor wholesome.
A cause of the wholesome but not wholesome refers to the eye element that is born of the retribution of the wholesome.
Neither a cause of the wholesome nor wholesome refers to the rest of the eye element.
The ear, nose, smell, tongue, taste, and body-contact elements are also like this.
The form element has three sentences.ğŸ”½Either a cause of the wholesome but not wholesome, referring to the form element that is born of the retribution of the wholesome.
Either wholesome and also a cause of the wholesome, referring to the wholesome form element.
Or neither wholesome nor unwholesome as cause, namely the other non-defined and unwholesome form of the form realm, excluding the form arisen from wholesome retribution.
The same applies to the six consciousnesses and the mind element.
The sound element has two alternatives.
Or wholesome and also wholesome as cause, namely the wholesome sound element.
Or neither wholesome nor wholesome as cause, namely the unwholesome and non-defined sound element.
The dharma element has four alternatives.
Or wholesome, not wholesome as cause, namely cessation obtained through contemplation.
Or wholesome as cause, not wholesome, namely the dharma element arisen from wholesome retribution.
Or wholesome and also wholesome as cause, namely the wholesome and conditioned dharma element.
Or neither wholesome nor wholesome as cause, namely the other non-defined and unwholesome dharma element, excluding the dharma element arisen from wholesome retribution.
How many are unwholesome but not due to unwholesome causes, etc.? All should be discriminated.
The eye element is either due to unwholesome causes but not unwholesome, or neither unwholesome nor due to unwholesome causes.
That which is not unwholesome but has unwholesome causes refers to the eye element that arises from the ripening of unwholesome karma.
That which is neither unwholesome nor has unwholesome causes refers to the remaining eye elements.
The ear, nose, smell, tongue, taste, body, and touch elements are also like this.
The form element has three cases.
That which is not unwholesome but has unwholesome causes refers to the form element that arises from the ripening of unwholesome karma.
That which is unwholesome and also has unwholesome causes refers to the unwholesome form element.

That which is neither unwholesome nor has unwholesome causes refers to the remaining form elements, which are neither wholesome nor unwholesome, and the wholesome form element, excluding the form element that arises from the ripening of unwholesome karma.
The eye, ear, nose, tongue, and body consciousness elements are also like this.
The sound element has two cases.
That which is unwholesome and also has unwholesome causes refers to the unwholesome sound element.
That which is neither unwholesome nor has unwholesome causes refers to the wholesome and indeterminate sound elements.
The mind element has three cases.

Or it is not unwholesome as cause but is unwholesome, namely, the mind element that is the result of unwholesome [action], and the mind element associated with the view of existence and the view of grasping extremes in the desire realm.
Or it is both unwholesome and unwholesome as cause, namely, the unwholesome mind element.

Or it is neither unwholesome nor unwholesome as cause, namely, the mind element that is wholesome and indeterminate, except for the mind element that is the result of unwholesome [action], and the mind element associated with the view of existence and the view of grasping extremes in the desire realm.
The same applies to the mind consciousness element.
The dharma element has three cases.

Or it is a cause of unwholesomeness but is not unwholesome, namely, the dharma element that arises from the result of unwholesome [action], and the dharma element associated with the view of existence and the view of grasping extremes in the desire realm, and the dharma element that arises together with them.
Or it is both unwholesome and a cause of unwholesomeness, namely, the unwholesome dharma element.

Or neither unwholesome nor with unwholesome as cause, namely, the element of dharmas that is not unwholesome karmic retribution, and except for the element of dharmas that is associated with and originated from the view of self in the realm of desire and the view grasping extremes in the realm of desire, the remaining indeterminate and wholesome elements.
As for how many are indeterminate and not with indeterminate as cause, etc., eight are indeterminate and also with indeterminate as cause, and ten should be distinguished.
That is to say, the form element has three sentences.
Or indeterminate and not with indeterminate as cause, namely, the unwholesome form element.
Or indeterminate and also with indeterminate as cause, namely, the indeterminate form element.
Or neither indeterminate nor with indeterminate as cause, namely, the wholesome form element.
The sound element, the six consciousness elements, and the mind element are also like this.
The dharma element has four sentences.
Or indeterminate and not with indeterminate as cause, namely, space and non-analytical cessation.
Or with indeterminate as cause and not indeterminate, namely, the unwholesome dharma element.
Or, they are indeterminate and have indeterminate factors as their causes, namely, the indeterminate conditioned factors.
Or, they are neither indeterminate nor have indeterminate factors as their causes, namely, the wholesome factors.
How many are causal conditions and also have causes, etc.? Seventeen are causal conditions and also have causes. One should be distinguished.
That is to say, if the factor realm is conditioned, it is a causal condition and also has causes. If it is unconditioned, it is neither a causal condition nor has causes.

How many are similar and immediately antecedent conditions but not similar and immediately antecedent causes, etc.? Ten are neither similar and immediately antecedent nor similar and immediately antecedent causes. Eight should be distinguished.

That is to say, the eye-consciousness realm has three sentences.ğŸ”½Either it is similar and immediately antecedent but not a similar and immediately antecedent cause, namely, the eye-consciousness that is about to arise in the future.ğŸ”½Either it is similar and immediately antecedent and also a similar and immediately antecedent cause, namely, the past and present eye-consciousness.

Or, it is neither similar and immediately antecedent nor a similar and immediately antecedent cause, namely, all future eye-consciousness except for the eye-consciousness that is about to arise in the future.
The same applies to the ear, nose, tongue, body, and consciousness realms.
The mind realm has three cases.

It is either a condition as the equivalent and immediate antecedent but not a condition as the equivalent and immediate antecedent, referring to the mind realm that is presently arising in the future, and the mind realm of an arhat who is in the process of passing away in the past and present.

It is either a condition as the equivalent and immediate antecedent and also a condition as the equivalent and immediate antecedent, referring to all the past and present mind realms, excluding the mind realm of an arhat who is in the process of passing away in the past and present.

It is neither a condition as the equivalent and immediate antecedent nor a condition as the equivalent and immediate antecedent, referring to all the future mind realms, excluding the mind realm that is presently arising in the future.
The same applies to the mind consciousness realm.
The dharma realm has three cases.

It is either a condition as the equivalent and immediate antecedent but not a condition as the equivalent and immediate antecedent, referring to all the mental factors that are presently arising in the future, and all the mental factors of an arhat who is in the process of passing away in the past and present, as well as the already arisen and presently occurring states of non-perception and cessation.

Or they are both immediately antecedent and immediately antecedent conditions, namely, all past and present mental factors other than the last thought and thought concomitants of an arhat's entry into nirvÄá¹‡a.

Or they are neither immediately antecedent nor immediately antecedent conditions, namely, all future mental factors other than those that will presently arise, all past and present non-associated compositional factors other than those that are immediately antecedent, all bodily and verbal actions, and unconditioned phenomena.

How many are objects of observation conditions but do not have objects of observation? Ten are objects of observation conditions but do not have objects of observation. Seven are both objects of observation conditions and have objects of observation. One should be differentiated.

That is, the phenomena element: if it is a mental factor, it is both an object of observation condition and has an object of observation; if it is not a mental factor, it is an object of observation condition but does not have an object of observation.
How many are dominant conditions but do not have dominance? Seventeen are dominant conditions and also have dominance. One should be differentiated.
It means the dharma realm. If it is conditioned, it is both an enabling cause and has enabling power. If it is unconditioned, it is an enabling cause but does not have enabling power.
How many are floods but not in conformity with floods, etc.? Fifteen are in conformity with floods but not floods, three should be distinguished.
It means the mind realm. If it is contaminated, it is in conformity with floods but not a flood. If it is uncontaminated, it is neither a flood nor in conformity with floods.
The mind consciousness realm is also like this.
The dharma realm has three sentences.
Either in conformity with floods but not a flood, referring to the contaminated dharma realm not included in the floods.
Either a flood and also in conformity with floods, referring to the four floods.
Either not a flood and not in conformity with floods, referring to the uncontaminated dharma realm.Here is the corrected and aligned text:
All-inclusive Treatise on the Categories of Existents, Scroll 17
